title: Font like Carpenter but more readable
content:
I have designed a direct mail piece using Carpenter for a few headlines. The client wants a font that is more "readable" while I don't want to change the look and feel too much. Any ideas for a substitute for Carpenter?

Thanks in advance,

KC
author: kaseycamille

comments.content:
How about Nick Curtis's ['Bayern Handschrift'](http://web.archive.org/web/20141201200949/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/bayern-handschrift-nf/)? It is a digitization of an old Art Nouveau era script typeface, so the time period is a good match for Carpenter.

- Mike Yanega

Also [Liorah](http://web.archive.org/web/20141201200949/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/bitstream/liorah_ot/). The drawback of these two is that they are more casual than Carpenter. If you want to maintain a more formal feeling, have a look at [Voluta Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20141201200949/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/monotype/voluta_script_pro_ot/).

Don't know if it's more legible for your customer, but [Johann Sparkling](http://web.archive.org/web/20141201200949/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/johann-sparkling-itc/) always reminds me somehow on Carpenter. BTW, Viktor Solt is the designer of Voluta Script, too.
Yeah, I omitted Johann because of the legibility factor. But I love it too.
